ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Being able to learn new grammar was a skill needed for this course.
In this course you continue to build from the skills in L1-L2 by refining your understanding of the grammar and verbal system.

Review of Middle Egyptian grammar with an introduction to Polotsky's Standard Theory as applied to the reading of literary texts; discussions of pertinent cultural and historical background interspersed throughout readings; overview of hieratic and rock inscriptions
Professor Darnell incorporates a wide range of content into the class. Practice with reading Egyptian texts is central but surrounded by many illuminating stories and details that provide a strong basis for further studies in Egyptology.

I better understanding of Egyptian Hieroglyphic that went beyond what I expected. I learned further grammatical forms used in middle egyptian, the grammatical forms in different interpretations, and how hieratic can sometimes impact the writing of glyphs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is well organized and is very accommodating.

The size of the class was a great strength. I felt that we were able to contribute and gain more experiences in class discussion. Also the sheer level of knowledge that Professor Darnell has about the grammar system and Egyptology was evident in the relaxed and encouraging manner in which the class was ran thsi semester. A weakness of the course was that there was sometimes a lack of structure in the course. It was difficult to try and keep up with the grammar that was just expected for us to learn on our time outside of class. It was difficult to take notes on learning to recoginze the grammar structures covered because we mainly discussed the topics as they came up, which would have been helpful for future retention and work.

Professor Darnell is an expert of the field and shares many spectacular stories to provide a broader understanding of Egyptian culture and history. The class is incredibly fun and interesting. The reading of the texts presents a good environment to review Middle Egyptian grammar while extending familiarity to new Standard Theory terminology. The difficulty of the class is largely determined by the student, facilitating learning by establishing a low stress setting in which additional resources are given for further exploration. While being less structured than expected, I found this to motivate intellectual curiosity and as an added advantage to the class. The midterm and final assessments were fair and helpful to gain practice with reading and analyzing grammatical forms. Overall, the course was an excellent seminar-style continuation of the Egyptian language sequence.
There were no weaknesses.

pro: super fun class with a very supportive professor
con: none

I found it perfect! I really enjoyed the informal discussions of the texts along with working through the translations and grammatical details in class. I thought that the exams were very fair and very useful in terms of learning; they were not that easy but, with time, doable and extremely worthwhile in terms of learning. I also appreciate the level of detail we went over the reading in.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you enjoyed taking L1 and L2, I would definitely recommend taking this class. At times that work assignments can be a bit much, but overall I thought that the pacing of the course was great and Professor Darnell was fantastic and it is clear that he truly has a passion for Egyptology that he wants to share with others.

Yes! This is an excellent continuation of the Egyptian language sequence that focuses on expanding knowledge of the grammatical system, introducing terminology from Polotsky's Standard Theory, and practice reading. We were able to see a broad selection of Egyptian literature, which is all quite fun. Professor Darnell makes the class super interesting with the inclusion of many stories about Egyptian culture and history. It is rewarding to apply your knowledge from L1/L2 to more texts in the original. Definitely take this class!
yes, I would! Professor Darnell is an amazing teacher and really cares about his students and their learning. He is also really passionate about Egyptology which makes the class very fun.
Yes.  Its a fascinating class and I really enjoyed it.

Absolutely! If you enjoyed L1 and L2, then I strongly suggest taking this course. You'll gain a deeper appreciation of the Egyptian writing system and really understand how to read hieroglyphic, including how the grammar is interpreted in different theories.
